text: The  procedures  and  problems  of  the  screening  model  used  by  the  National  Cancer  Institute  of  the  United  States  (US-NCI)  was  illustrated  by  M.R.  Boyd  (Beth-  esda).  He  briefly  summarized  the  three  phases  of  anti-  cancer drug development, which are drug discovery, pre-  clinical development and  clinical evaluation.  Whereas  it  might be desirable that the influx of drugs into this three-  step procedure is steered by a rational approach, the ma-  jority of drugs coming into this system have an empirical  background.  During  the  years  1975-1985  the NCI  used  the  P388  mouse  leukemia  in  vivo model  as  the primary  screen to  make  the  first decision whether a  drug  should  be tested further in a  panel  of five murine and  three hu-  *  This meeting was sponsored by the Association of Medical On-  cology (AIO) in the German Cancer Society and organized by the  phase I/II-Study Group of the AIO  W o l f  gang  E.  Berdel  i  and  H e i n z - H .   Fiebig  z  The  development of cytostatic anticancer drugs  was  the  subject  of  a  meeting  held  in  Frankfurt  on  23-24  November,  1989.  The  meeting  focused  on  preclinical  studies  and  early clinical  trials  with  new  cytotoxic anti-  cancer drugs.  It  was  organized by  the  Phase  I-II  Study  Group  of the AIO,  German  Cancer  Society, which con-  sists  of a phase II study group, and in which just recently  a phase I study group has  been founded.  Cytostatic  anticancer  drug development: preclinical  studies  and early  clinical trials  (Frankfurt/Main,  November  1989)*  Received 24 January 1990/Accepted 26 January 1990

The  main  goal  of  this  meeting  was  to  provide  the  scientists and clinicians active in this field with a compre-  hensive overview of the models, methodology and prob-  lems  within  the  development  of  anticancer  drugs.  The  meeting had four sessions.  Abbreviations:  MTD, maximum tolerated dose; AUC, area under  curve  Of Jj~rint requests to." W. E. Berdel  2 Divison of Hematology and Oncology, Department of Internal Medicine, University of Freiburg,  1 Division of Hematology and Oncology, Department of Medicine I, Technische Universitfit,  (Chairpersons: D.  Schm/ihl, Heidelberg,  and  B. W.  Fox, Manchester)  J Cancer Res Clin Oncol (1990) 116:224-227  HugstetterstraBe 55, D-7800 Freiburg, Federal Republic of Germany  Ismaninger Street 22, D-8000 Munich 80, Federal Republic of Germany

man  tumors  and  subsequently  go  to  formulation  and  toxicology.  In  this  period  approximately  $115  million  were spent for preclinical studies. Among the compounds  selected for clinical trials  during  the  last  10 years,  how-  ever, only a few were active in leukemias and lymphomas  but none at all in slowly growing solid tumors. This neg-  ative  outcome  led  to  a  reformulation  of  the  screening  strategy. Now  all new compounds  are tested in vitro for  growth inhibition in a panel that currently has 58 human  tumor  cell  lines.  Various  test  assays  have  been  investi-  gated for the primary screening, among  them the sulfor-  hodamine B assay. This tumor cell line panel contains all  major  tumor  types  including  carcinomas  of  the  lung,  brain,  kidney, colon,  ovary, melanomas  and  leukemias.  Compounds  with  a  disease-specific activity  are  studied  further  in  nude  mice  against  the  most  sensitive  tumor  lines.  From  the  in  vitro  screening  interesting  finger-  print-like  evaluations  can  be  obtained  for  activity  and  inactivity  of  a  compound.  This  fingerprint  evaluation  (e.g.  ICso  values)  picks  out  alkylating  agents,  for  ex-  ample,  as  being  similar,  and  is  also  able  to  detect other  classes  of drugs with similar mechanisms of action. Com-  pounds that successfully pass both the in vitro and the in  vivo screening are prepared  for formulation,  toxicology  and  clinical testing.  The NCI  is  still  in  the  development  phase  of this new screening system; it anticipates testing  a minimum of 10 000 compounds per year in 100 cell lines  at a  cost of approximately $ 3 million per year.

Interestingly, M. Boyd mentioned that more than half  of the drugs acquired by the NCI from Europe in the past  were  coming  from  West  Germany.  This  further  under-  lines the importance for a  concentrated effort within the  Federal  Republic  of Germany  to  set  up  own  screening  systems and an active phase I clinical trials group.  W.J. Zeller from the German Cancer Research Center  in Heidelberg discussed the suitability of autochthonous  tumor models in rats for secondary screening. Chemically  induced tumors exist for almost all important tumor loca-  tions; however, they have not been used very frequently.  Cancer ~esearch  Clinical (cid:14)9  @ Springer-Verlag 1990  In the discussion it was felt that whereas a variety of  new promising screening models exist,  the actual bottle-  neck of the preclinical screening of new anticancer drugs  is  the  lack  of  active,  new  compounds.  However,  com-  pounds that were inactive in the previous murine test sys-  tems should be considered for retesting in the new screen-  ing models.

A  combined in  vitro/in vivo  system was  outlined by  D.  Berger,  B.  Winterhalter,  and  H.H.  Fiebig  from  the  University of Freiburg. This group uses a four-stage sys-  tem. New compounds are studied initially in vitro for cy-  totoxicity in human  tumor  xenografts and  human bone  marrow  colony-forming units  culture  assays  (CFU-C)  as well as in the leukemia P388,  using a  modification of  the  clonogenic assay.  The  in  vitro  screening  is  done  in  4 highly sensitive  xenografts (small cell and large cell of  the lung, breast and stomach) and 2 resistant xenografts  (renal  and  colon) as  well  as  in P388.  Secondary in vitro  screening is performed in a  total of 14 responsive and  6  resistant human tumor xenografts and in 2 4   CFU-C as-  says.  Compounds with a  greater  or  similar effect on  tu-  mor cells, as compared to human bone marrow, are sub-  sequently studied  in  vivo  in  the  2  most  sensitive  xeno-  grafts transplanted  subcutaneously into  nude mice.  The  comparison  of in  vitro/in vivo activity allows an  assess-  ment  of the  relevant in  vitro  dose  based  on  the  in  vivo  pharmacological  behaviour  of  a  compound.  If  a  re-  mission or  at  least no  change is  observed in  vivo a  new  compound  undergoes  disease-oriented  testing  in  4060  xenografts. Characteristics of the selected tumors and the  effect of new drugs were presented.  Several  had been se-  lected for phase I studies, which are under way within the  EORTC,  the CRC and the US-NCI.

H.P.  Kraemer  (Behringwerke,  Marburg)  presented  data  of  a  screening  system  with  initial  in  vitro  and  broader in vivo steps.  Instead of using the subcutaneous  xenograft model for in vivo testing, the group in Marburg  has developed a modified subrenal capsule assay. Work-  ing from the fact that the form of this assay introduced  by Bogden et al. has several  disadvantages, including tu-  mor rejection, irreproducible growth in the controls, vari-  ation in tumor size because of fat, necrosis and lymphoid  infiltration and others, the Behring Group first produces  homogeneous tumor cell/fibrin clots in  glass capillaries.  These  clots  are  then  cut  into  identical  pieces  and  im-  planted  under  the  renal  capsule  of nude  mice.  Tests  of  compounds such as theprubicin, Adriamycin and differ-  ent platinum analogues showed similar results to those in  the subcutaneous model.  Autochthonous  tumors  usually  show  a  slower  growth  rate  than  transplantable  tumors.  There  seems  to  be  a  good  correlation  between  response  to  treatment  in  au-  tochthonous leukemia and breast tumor models in com-  parison to the clinical situation. There is some predictiv-  ity for various combination chemotherapy regimens. Au-  tochthonous  leukemias  provide  excellent  experimental  models for various  aspects  of autologous bone  marrow  transplantation. W.J. Zeller further elaborated on experi-  ments  resulting  in  the  identification of interesting  new  compounds such  as  hexadecylphosphocholine, titanium  complexes and ruthenium derivatives.

There do  not  exist minimal requirements for clinical  phase I trials in the Federal Republic of Germany as part  of  the  law.  However,  detailed  recommendations  have  been worked out in cooperation with the Bundesgesund-  heitsamt.  They  were  published  in  the  Bundesanzeiger  (no. 123, 2965; 1988). V. Schmidt from the Bundesgesund-  heitsamt  in  Berlin  presented  these  recommendations,  which,  in  agreement with  paragraph  40  of the  German  Arzneimittelgesetz,  are  based  on  risk/benefit  analysis.  These recommendations far exceed the minimal require-  ments  as  formulated by  the  CRC.  There  was  some  dis-

B.W.  Fox (Manchester) reported  on the goals of the  Cancer Research Campaign (CRC) in Great Britain. Ef-  forts are made by this multidisciplinary group to coordi-  nate all aspects of preclinical development and to initiate  the clinical phase I and II studies.  The CRC has the capac-  ity of preparing approximately six drugs per year. Selec-  tion criteria for drugs are novel structures (no analogues)  with  selected  biological activity in  experimental  tumors  and/or  normal  tissues,  availability  of  adequate  drug  quantities,  availability of formulation  facilities  and  the  presence  of  interested  clinicians.  The  minimal  require-  ments for preclinical toxicology of this group include the  establishment  of the  LD~0  (lethal  dose  for  10%  of the  animals)  in  mice.  In  these  experiments  single  doses  are  given i.p.,  i.v.,  p.o.  and  multiple times  i.p.  Hematology  studies  and  histopathology are  performed of all  impor-  tant  tissues  including bone  marrow  and,  for  endocrine  compounds, including ovary, adrenals etc.  The schedule  selected  for clinical studies is also  tested in rats;  10%  of  the  LD10  in mice must be  non-toxic in order to provide  a  safe starting dose.  The recommended starting dose for  clinical phase I trials is  10%  of the mouse LDlo, and ei-  ther  modified  Fibonacci  schemes  or  pharmacokinetic  methods relating the area under the curve (AUC) in mice  and  man  are  proposed  for  dose  escalation.  Approxi-  mately  30  compounds  from  different  chemical  classes  such  as  bryostatins,  elactocin,  pyridoglutethimide and  antagonists  of  the  platelet-activating  factor  have  been  evaluated in this system up to now.

Tremendous difficulties can occur when larger quantities  of an investigational anticancer compound are to be syn-  thesized  and  formulated  for  preclinical  toxicology and  clinical trials.  Some of these problems include solubility,  identity of the drug, limited availability, the purity of the  material obtained, and stability. Thus, an EORTC-CRC-  NCI  Working  Party  on  formulation has  been  founded.  J.A.  Slack,  Birmingham,  reported  that  this  working  party,  which has  been  in  existence for 2  years,  has  suc-  cessfully formulated batches  of various  hydrophilic and  lipophilic  compounds  for  clinical  trials.  It  has  further-  more published guidelines on  formulation (Davignon et  al.).  Furthermore,  there  are  6-monthly meetings  of this  working party for the discussion of documentation stan-  dards,  status  of drugs in formulation and general prob-  lems that may occur.  Formulation, preclinical toxicology and pharmacology  (Chairpersons: O. C. Yoder,  Brussels,  and G.  Eisenbrand, Kaiserslautern)  cussion  on  the  critical  question  of  whether  detailed  toxicological studies in  animals  other  than mice  or  rats  are predictive for toxicity in human phase I clinical trials.  The critical question arose:  is it justifiable to enter more  patients into phase I trials than are actually necessary by  predicting  toxicity at  a  falsely low  dose  level?  This  has  been  the  case  in  some  of the  pase I  trials  recently per-  formed.

In the subsequent panel discussion (Chairman: H.H.  Fiebig,  University  of  Freiburg)  B.  Winograd  from  the  New  Drug  Development  Office of the  EORTC  in  Am-  sterdam  pointed  out  that  19/20  compounds  are  safe  in  phase I trials when 10%  of the mouse equivalent LD10 is  used as a starting dose. Dog toxicity in his opinion would  predict  toxicity at  a  too  low dose level.  Methodology of clinical phase I trials

The aims and methodology of clinical phase I trials with  investigational  anticancer  drugs  were  outlined  by  Dr.  Sessa,  Bellinzona, secretary of the  Early  Clinical Trials  Group of the EORTC. This organisation defines the ma-  jor  goal  of phase I  studies  as  finding a  maximum toler-  ated  and  safe dose for phase II  trials,  the major goal of  phase II trials as detecting clinical antitumor activity and  providing some clues  for phase III  trials,  and  the major  goal  of phase III  trials  as  establishing  the  efficacy and  side-effects  of  a  new  anticancer  drug  in  comparison  to  standard  drugs.  Detailed  aims  of phase I  trials  are  the  definition of the maximum tolerated dose (MTD),  dose-  limiting  toxicity, its  reversibility,  relation  of toxicity to  dose  and  schedule,  and  recommendations  for  phase II  trials. The EORTC defines the MTD as being reached for  hematologic toxicity, if at least 50%  of the patients expe-  rience toxicity of grade 2, but fewer than 20%  of the pa-  tients have toxicity of grade 3.  Dr.  Sessa  stressed that it  is important to  follow standard  toxicity criteria, such as  are published by the World Health Organization (1979).  The EORTC uses  1/6 of the mouse LDlo or 1/3 of the  ,toxic  dose  low'  in  the  dog,  whichever  is  lower,  as  the  starting dose. Three patients are treated per dose level. A  modified Fibonacci procedure  or  procedures  according  to pharmacokinetic data (AUC) are used for dose escala-  tion. There still  is a controversial discussion of the ques-  tion  whether  intraindividual dose  escalation  should  be  performed. Factors that argue in favour of this procedure  are,  for  instance,  the  higher  chances  of  therapeutic  re-  sponses  in  phase  I  trials.  Among  factors  that  argue  against this procedure are that cumulative toxicity cannot

be  performed. Factors that argue in favour of this procedure  are,  for  instance,  the  higher  chances  of  therapeutic  re-  sponses  in  phase  I  trials.  Among  factors  that  argue  against this procedure are that cumulative toxicity cannot  be judged.  The  MTD  should  not  necessarily be  always  reached in phase I trials, e.g.  if it becomes clear during a  phase I study that plasma levels of the drug active in ani-  mals cannot be reached in humans. The major open ques-  tions in the conductance of phase I trials are how to per-  form  this  study type with chemotherapy plus  a  colony-  stimulating factor or other active proteins, as well as how  to perform this study type with biological response modi-  fiers and hormonal agents.

(Chairpersons: W. Queiger, Mannheim,  and R.  Herrmann, Berlin)  A  highlight  of the  conference was  the  discussion  of  ethical and legal considerations in phase I trials by H. M.  Sass,  Washington. Ethical monitoring of phase I trials is  no unprofessional intrusion into the medical field; on the  contrary, it is an integral part  of each early clinical  trial.  Ethical  aspects  with  specific  importance  within phase I  trials are the special  uncertainty with regard to potential  harm  and  the  underestimation  of  potential  risks  (nil  nocere?),  the  low  efficacy  of  the  study  type  (bonum  facere?),  the informed consent of the patient and the in-  formed cooperation  between  the  physician and  patient,  the  participation  of  ethical  committees  including  lay  persons in the decision-making process and the monitor-  ing of phase I trials, although the physician accepts final  responsibility and finally the covenant concept with mu-  L.  Edler  from  the  Deutsches  Krebsforschungszen-  trum in Heidelberg discussed details of statistical require-  ments  and  documentation for  phase I  trials.  Obtaining  the maximum information for toxicity with the shortest  time and lowest patient numbers possible, is accepted as  a principle goal of phase I trials, and strategies were dis-  cussed to calculate the MTD  in patient populations with  confidence limits, which might be more exact than to give  individual  MTD  values.  However,  it  is  questionable  whether  this  strategy would  prevent  dose  de-escalation  steps,  which sometimes are necessary for recommending  phase  II  trial doses.

G.  Ehninger,  University  of  Tiibingen,  reviewed  the  pharmacokinetics necessary during phase I  studies. Bio-  availability certainly is  a  major  problem  for  drugs  that  are given p.o. For different cytotoxic drugs gastrointesti-  nal  uptake  can  show  a  virtual  variation between  0  and  100%  in relation to food uptake, for example. Drug effi-  cacy,  however,  is  strongly  related  to  bioavailability.  Thus,  pharmacokinetic  measurements  in  early  clinical  trials  are  most  important.  Furthermore, with  the  AUC  known  from  preclinical  animal  experiments  and  com-  parisons  between  AUC  values  in  mice  and  man,  the  modified Fibonacci dose-escalation procedure can be re-  placed  by  pharmakokinetic  procedures.  Whereas  with  the Fibonacci method up  to  13 dose-escalation steps  are  necessary,  Collins  et  al.  have  been  showing  that,  with  comparative  pharmacokinetic  dose-escalation  pro-  cedures,  approximately  5-6  dose-escalation  steps  will  lead to the MTD  for a few drugs.

Further  details  on  dose  escalations,  based  on  com-  parative preclinical and  clinical  pharmakokinetics, were  subsequently discussed by A. H. Calvert, Newcastle upon  Tyne.  Problems  connected  to  the  AUC-related  method  can  occur when either active or  toxic metabolites of the  actual  drug  are  not  taken  into  consideration.  Further-  more  the  parmacokinetic  assay  measuring  the  drug  plasma  levels  must  be  of sufficient sensitivity to  detect  10%  of the mouse LD1o. Thus the pharmacokinetics and  metabolism (PAM)-group  of the  EORTC  has proposed  that one should determine both  the  LD10 AUC  and the  LDso  AUC,  and  furthermore determine binding  of the  drug  and  its  metabolites  to  plasma  in  mouse  and  man.  Other problems occurring are the great variability of the  AUC  in  individual  patients  (carboplatin  at  one  dose:  360  750 gM  x  min).  in  the  last  session  of  this  symposium  M.J.  Hawkins,  NCI/USA,  Bethesda, gave an overview on phase I  stud-  ies recently performed by the US-NCI.  In  the year 1988  more than 600 patients were entered on phase I trial pro-

tual  trust.  Risk-reduction  strategies  are  represented  by  refinement of phase I pilot  studies,  thorough patient se-  lection according to factors such as health status, patient-  oriented  dose  escalation,  one-center  instead  of  multi-  center trials, and improved interaction between preclini-  cal  studies  and  early  clinical  trials,  as  well  as  the  ap-  plication process of an investigational new drug with the  legal authorities. Medical, legal and moral guidelines for  phase  I  studies  are  the  Helsinki  declaration,  the  Tokyo  declaration  and  the  national  legal  regulations  for  such  studies,  which  contain  such  important  aspects  as  bene-  fit/risk  evaluation,  informed  consent  and  ethical  board  guidelines.  In  addition  questionnaires  for  the  ethical  board, addressing moral microissues of phase I trials, as  well  as  continuous  ethical  monitoring  throughout  the  phase  I  studies  are  advisable.  The  technical  reports  on  the results of phase I trials have to be exact and reliable;  however, they must concentrate in more detail on ethical  aspects  than  they have  done in  the past.  Results of phase I studies  (Chairpersons: W. E.  Berdel,  Mfinchen,  and M. E.  Heim, Mannheim)  In the summary H. H.  Fiebig (Freiburg)  reported  on  the  phase  I  trial  group  of  the  AIO,  which was  recently  founded. The goal of this group is to test approximately  three  compounds  in  two  schedules  with  approximately  six studies per year. These studies will include pharmaco-  kinetic analysis. H.H.  Fiebig stressed the importance of  good  cooperation  with  the  preclinical  research  team  in  anticancer  drug  development  and  announced  that  the  group will further discuss the  guidelines for minimal re-  quirements before starting a phase I trial and the qualifi-  cation  criteria  for  oncology centers  performing phase I  trials within this group.
